Topline
A state appeals court struck down a Pennsylvania law allowing no-excuse mail-in voting as unconstitutional Friday, with potentially strong implications for the battleground state—though the ruling will not impact the state’s upcoming primary elections and could be reversed by the State Supreme Court.

Judges on the Pennsylvania Commonwealth Court, which has a Republican majority, ruled that while no-excuse mail-in voting makes voting “more convenient,” it conflicts with the state’s Constitution and its requirement that people vote in person.

Democratic voting rights advocates told the Philadelphia Inquirer before the ruling they believed even a temporary loss could be damaging, however, as it could further sow people’s distrust in the state’s electoral system.
The legal challenge against Act 77 is part of a broader GOP effort to restrict voting access in the wake of the 2020 election, including both in court and by enacting more restrictive voting laws.
Any changes to Pennsylvania’s mail-in voting procedures could carry heavy implications in the battleground state, which President Joe Biden narrowly won in 2020 with just 50.01% of the vote.
